**M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: The court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 212, § 4**, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

**M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **M.G.L. c. 223, § 1**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Springfield, Massachusetts, within Hampden County.

**M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every individual has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating conditions that pose a foreseeable risk of harm to others. See **M.G.L. c. 231, § 85**; **Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 386 Mass. 281, 285 (1982)**.

**Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 386.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every individual has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating conditions that pose a foreseeable risk of harm to others. See **M.G.L. c. 231, § 85**; **Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 386 Mass. 281, 285 (1982)**.
**Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 386.support_reasoning: The opinion in Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. reproduced here is a criminal procedure/Fourth Amendment case dealing with the legality of an arrest across state lines and the existence of probable cause. It does not discuss general negligence principles, duties of reasonable care, or M.G.L. c. 231, § 85. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the broad tort proposition that every individual has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm to others.
**Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 386.relevant_excerpt: "Probable cause to arrest exists when, at the moment of arrest, the facts and circumstances known to the police officers were sufficient to warrant a person of reasonable caution in believing that the defendant had committed or was committing a crime."

**Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist.,.raw_text: **Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist., 53 N.Y.2d 325, 329 (1981)**
**Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist.,.proposition: Defendant had an affirmative duty to ensure that the aluminum extension ladder on his property was properly secured to prevent it from falling and causing harm to individuals or property. See **Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist., 53 N.Y.2d 325, 329 (1981)** (discussing the standard of care for property owners); **Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 Mass. 505, 507-08 (1950)** (duty of care requires addressing foreseeable risks).
**Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist.,.case_name: Akins v. Glens Falls City School District
**Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist.,.support_reasoning: The case addresses the general duty of a landowner to exercise reasonable care but in the specific context of a baseball field owner’s obligation to protect spectators from foul balls. It holds that the proprietor is not an insurer and that reasonable care is satisfied by providing adequate screening in the most dangerous area, behind home plate. It does not establish or discuss any affirmative duty of a property owner to secure an aluminum extension ladder or analogous equipment; using Akins for that specific ladder-duty proposition misstates its holding and context.
**Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist.,.relevant_excerpt: "Rather, like any other owner or occupier of land, it is only under a duty to exercise 'reasonable care under the circumstances' to prevent injury to those who come to watch the games played on its field. (Basso v Miller, 40 NY2d 233; Scurti v City of New York, 40 NY2d 433.)"

**Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 M.raw_text: **Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 Mass. 505, 507-08 (1950)**
**Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 M.proposition: Defendant had an affirmative duty to ensure that the aluminum extension ladder on his property was properly secured to prevent it from falling and causing harm to individuals or property. See **Akins v. Glens Falls City Sch. Dist., 53 N.Y.2d 325, 329 (1981)** (discussing the standard of care for property owners); **Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 Mass. 505, 507-08 (1950)** (duty of care requires addressing foreseeable risks).
**Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 M.case_name: Black v. Boston Consolidated Gas Co.
**Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 M.support_reasoning: The case concerns a gas company’s duty to maintain underground gas mains and to anticipate and prevent foreseeable breaks; it does not involve ladders, conditions on private premises, or an affirmative duty to secure an aluminum extension ladder. While the opinion discusses foreseeability and a duty of reasonable care in maintaining dangerous instrumentalities (gas mains), extending that to a specific duty to secure a ladder overstates and mischaracterizes the holding. Thus, it offers only very general support on foreseeability, not the specific proposition claimed.
**Black v. Boston Consol. Gas Co., 325 M.relevant_excerpt: “The jury were warranted in finding that the defendant should reasonably have anticipated that a break might occur; that it negligently failed to prevent it; and that the defendant did not exercise reasonable care in the maintenance and supervision of its gas main used by it to convey a substance of a dangerous nature having a tendency to escape, which, if not kept confined to the main, might result in serious harm to another.” (325 Mass. at 508-09).

**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to secure the ladder despite Plaintiff’s warnings. See **Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973)** (landowners owe a duty to act reasonably under all the circumstances); **Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc., 10 Mass. App. Ct. 888, 888-89 (1980)**.
**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is from a concurrence discussing the abandonment of rigid common-law status categories (licensee/invitee/trespasser) and criticizing a footnote about trespassers. It does not mention any duty to secure a ladder, any factual context similar to the proposition, or even directly articulate the general rule that landowners must act reasonably under all the circumstances. While the full Mounsey decision is indeed known for adopting a general reasonable-care standard to lawful visitors, this specific quoted text does not clearly state or apply that rule, so on the basis of the text provided it does not support the proposition as cited.
**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

**Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc.raw_text: **Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc., 10 Mass. App. Ct. 888, 888-89 (1980)**
**Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to secure the ladder despite Plaintiff’s warnings. See **Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973)** (landowners owe a duty to act reasonably under all the circumstances); **Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc., 10 Mass. App. Ct. 888, 888-89 (1980)**.
**Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a landowner’s duty of reasonable care in premises liability (specifically, securing a ladder after warnings). Townsley, as quoted here, is a criminal case about arson, prosecutorial obligations regarding evidence, and sufficiency of evidence for conviction. It does not discuss landowner duties, negligence, premises liability, or any duty to secure a ladder, so it cannot support the stated negligence proposition.
**Townsley v. Woburn Foreign Motors, Inc.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals from his conviction of arson of a dwelling house (G. L. c. 266, § 1) and claims error in the denial of his motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that the Commonwealth failed to produce a light fixture which would exculpate him, and in the denial of his motions for a directed verdict. He also claims that he was denied due process because the prosecutor failed to keep a promise to dismiss the charges. We affirm.

**Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 M.raw_text: **Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 Mass. App. Ct. 508, 511 (1996)**
**Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 M.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably created a foreseeable risk of harm that directly and proximately caused damage to Plaintiff’s vehicle. See **Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 Mass. App. Ct. 508, 511 (1996)** (foreseeability establishes duty and breach); **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)** (reasonableness evaluated based on foreseeability of harm).
**Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 M.support_reasoning: This case is a criminal search-and-seizure decision about reasonable suspicion and a protective frisk leading to discovery of heroin. It does not concern civil negligence, duty, breach, proximate cause, vehicle damage, or foreseeability of harm in a tort context. Citing it for the proposition that a defendant’s failure to act reasonably created a foreseeable risk of harm that proximately caused damage to a vehicle misstates the subject and holding of the opinion.
**Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 M.relevant_excerpt: "The issue in evaluating the validity of the police action that discovered Joe’s illegal drugs is whether all the circumstances faced by Officer Grant, taken together, were ‘enough to warrant belief by a ‘reasonably prudent man . . . that his safety or that of others was in danger.’ ... Grant’s action was undoubtedly a warrantless search, but it was within constitutional limits, being ‘confined to what was minimally necessary to learn whether the suspect [was] armed.’"

**Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc..raw_text: **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)**
**Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc..proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably created a foreseeable risk of harm that directly and proximately caused damage to Plaintiff’s vehicle. See **Levine v. Stop & Shop Cos., Inc., 40 Mass. App. Ct. 508, 511 (1996)** (foreseeability establishes duty and breach); **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)** (reasonableness evaluated based on foreseeability of harm).
**Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc..case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
**Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc..support_reasoning: The provided text is a concurring opinion that applies a foreseeability analysis to the specific facts, concluding the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm. It does not clearly state the broader doctrinal proposition that reasonableness is evaluated based on foreseeability of harm, nor does it discuss duty/breach in the general way claimed. The citation therefore overstates what Poskus stands for doctrinally, at least based on the excerpt given.
**Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc..relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

**Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc.raw_text: **Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc., 391 Mass. 372, 379 (1984)**
**Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered damages, including repair costs, car rental expenses, and payment of her insurance deductible. See **Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc., 391 Mass. 372, 379 (1984)** (plaintiff entitled to damages directly resulting from defendant’s negligence).
**Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a criminal appeal concerning prosecutorial argument, mugshot evidence, and miscarriage of justice in a murder conviction. It does not discuss civil negligence, proximate cause, or recoverable categories of damages such as repair costs, rental car expenses, or insurance deductibles. The citation to Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc., 391 Mass. 372, 379 (1984) appears to be incorrect or mismatched to this opinion, so this text does not support the stated damages proposition.
**Pittard v. Four Seasons Motor Inn, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Finally, considering the defendant’s contentions and the trial as a whole, the jury’s verdict was not “against the weight of the evidence considered in a large or nontechnical sense,” Commonwealth v. Bowman, 373 Mass. 760, 765 (1977), nor did his conviction constitute a miscarriage of justice. Therefore, we decline to invoke our power under G. L. c. 278, § 33E. Our job is not to sit as a second jury passing anew on the defendant’s guilt. Commonwealth v. Reddick, 372 Mass. 460, 464 (1977).
